sideA: Esa rama es la que tiene cambios que necesitamos traer.

sideB.text: That branch is the one with the changes we need to pull.
That branch has the changes we need to bring in.
That's the branch that contains the changes we need to merge.
That branch is the one which has the changes we need to pull.

note: In Git terminology, [Pull], [Bring in], or [Merge] are used for bringing changes from one branch to another.

sideB.text: Other than those ones.
Besides those.
Apart from those.
Other than those.

note:
**[128]**

Use [other than] or [apart from] to exclude specific elements from a selection.

~Not those~ (Incorrect: This is a fragment used for pointing/rejection, not for expressing exclusion in a sentence.)

~Than not be those~ (Incorrect: Literal translation that doesn't follow English syntax for exclusion.)

sideA: La inicialización es donde le decimos a Oracle: ¿Quién pregunta?

sideB.text: Initialization is where we tell Oracle: Who's asking?
The init phase is where we define for Oracle: Who is requesting?
The setup is where we let Oracle know: Who is the caller?

note:
In a database context, [Initialization] or [Init] refers to the process of setting up the session variables or security context.

~Initialization is where we say Oracle: Who's asking?~ (Incorrect: 'Say' requires [to] before a recipient; use 'tell Oracle' or 'say to Oracle'.)

sideB.text: Above the UNION: Special rules.
Over the UNION: Special rules.
The part before the UNION: Special rules.

note:
**[155]**

[Above] refers to the code lines that appear before the SQL [UNION] operator.

~Up the UNION~ (Incorrect: 'Up' is a direction, use [above] for spatial hierarchy.)

~Upper the UNION~ (Incorrect: 'Upper' is an adjective, not a preposition.)

sideA: Estamos esperando que sean de ese tipo.

sideB.text: We are hoping they are of that type.
We are expecting them to be that kind.
We're hoping those are the type.

note:
Positive counterpart of the previous card. Notice that after [hope], we use a normal sentence: [they are...]. After [expect], we often use an infinitive structure: [expect them TO BE...].

~We are expecting those kind~ / ~We are expecting those type~ (Incorrect: [Those] is plural and requires plural nouns like [kinds] or [types], or use 'that kind'.)

sideA: Le di un vistazo a eso, y te cuento que...

sideB.text: I took a look at that, and let me tell you...
I've had a look at it, and I'll let you know...
I checked that out, and here is what I found...
I took a look at that, and I'll let you know...

note:
[Take a look] or [Check out] are the standard phrases for 'dar un vistazo'.

[Let me tell you] is used to introduce the feedback.

~I let you know~ (Incorrect: When promising information in the future, you must use the future [will] or [I'll].)

sideA: Buscaré la traducción de lo que quiero decir.

sideB.text: I will look up the translation for what I want to say.
I am going to find the translation of what I mean.
I will search for the translation of my intended meaning.
I will look the translation up for what I want to say.
I will look up the translation of what I want to say.

note:
[What I mean] is often more natural than the literal 'what I want to say' in a conversation.

~I will look the translation for what I want to say~ (Incorrect: Searching requires the particle [up] to complete the phrasal verb.)

Both [of] and [for] are correct here. Use [for] to emphasize the purpose (a translation intended for a phrase) and [of] to emphasize the content (the translation belonging to that phrase).
